Award.AwardTitle: Computational Motivic and Equivariant Homotopy Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spheres are simple yet important objects of study in topology. One of the central questions of algebraic topology is to classify all of the possible mappings of a sphere of a given dimension onto a sphere of different dimension. More recently, this question has received attention in other contexts: when the spheres are considered in the realm of algebraic geometry, or when the spheres have specified symmetries which must be preserved by the mappings in question. Even more recently, greater understanding of how these various contexts impact each other has emerged. The PI will endeavor to expand the range in which these questions are understood, especially in the setting of spheres with a twofold symmetry. Another component of the project focuses on an invariant known as K-theory, which lies at the interface of topology and algebra. The PI will develop a version of K-theory which is simultaneously equipped with symmetries and multiplications.

The PI will continue his joint work with Dan Isaksen on computations in the motivic and C2-equivariant stable homotopy groups of spheres. The computation of motivic stable homotopy groups over C is fairly similar to that of classical stable homotopy groups. From there, the Bockstein spectral sequence recovers the motivic stable homotopy groups over R. Finally, accounting for the "negative cone" in the C2-equivariant homology of a point leads to the equivariant stable homotopy groups. In a different direction the PI, together with May, Merling, and Osorno, will continue to investigate the presentation of G-spectra as spectral Mackey functors. A centerpiece of this theory is an equivariant infinite loop space machine with good multiplicative properties. A number of tools that figure centrally in applications, such as equivariantly commutative multiplications, norm maps, and geometric fixed points, are not well understood in this model of G-spectra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Homotopy theory is the study of spaces up to continuous deformation. Many algebraic invariants have been developed to assist in the study of spaces up to homotopy. Of primary importance are the higher homotopy groups.
When the spaces being studied have specified symmetries, codified through group actions, we require the deformations to respect the symmetries, or group actions, which leads to equivariant homotopy theory. Once again, several algebraic invariants, such as homotopy groups, can be used for this study.

The intellectual merit of this project was largely in two directions: computations in C2-equivariant stable homotopy theory, on the one hand, and the development of multiplicative equivariant infinite loop space theory, on the other.

The line of approach towards C2-equivariant stable homotopy theory in this project is motivic homotopy theory. Betti realization provides a bridge between R-motivic homotopy theory and C2-equivariant homotopy theory. The first steps in this program have been carried out by the PI and collaborators under support of this grant. One case of this is the article of Guillou-Hill-Isaksen-Ravenel, in which the PI and collaborators employed the R-motivic-to-C2-equivariant approach to compute the homotopy groups of C2-equivariant connective real K-theory. The more recent article of Guillou-Isaksen, in which the PI and Isaksen recover some early results of Bredon and Landweber from this new point of view, is the beginning of work to compute equivariant stable stems.

The PI and his collaborators May, Merling, and Osorno worked during the scope of this grant to produce a machine that takes in G-equivariant symmetric monoidal categories and produces G-spectra in such a way that additional multiplicative structure on the input categories yields multiplicative structure on the output G-spectra. The most recent article in this collaboration uses the language of multicategories and multifunctors to describe and produce this multiplicative machine. This has allowed the PI and May to complete their earlier work that describes G-spectra as spectral Mackey functors, but is also expected to have much wider application.

The grant had broader impact in the training of graduate students and postdocs. During the scope of this grant, the PI advised two PhD students, two postdocs, as well as a masters student. The PI funded student travel through the grant. In addition, the PI organized two conferences while supported by this grant.
